It depends what you have in your Spring XML.  Often it is the
equivalent of=
 "new" statements, defining the internal structure of the
code, rather than=
 application configuration.  If that is the case,
then you should test with=
 the same Spring XML as you use in the real
application.  Make sure the Spr=
ing XML contains no connection details
for your database.  Configure those =
in a different way (properties
files for example).  Have different connecti=
on parameters for your
test database and your production database.  

In yo=
ur persistence tests, clear the test database and call the
BankImpl (for ex=
ample) to check that it can round-trip your persistent
objects.  That will =
test that Spring, Hibernate and your code all
integrate together correctly.=


Be careful with transactions and Hibernate's first-level cache so that
yo=
u're really are round-tripping objects into and out of the database
and not=
 just using local copies from the EntityManager's cache.

--Nat
